statement:
Let $X$ be a Hausdorff space, let $A$ be a compact non-empty set in $X$,
and let $y$ a point in the complement of $A$. Then there exist disjoint
open sets $U$ and $V$ in $X$ such that $A\subset U$ and $y\in V$.

First we use the fact that $X$ is a Hausdorff space. Thus, for all
$x\in A$ there exist disjoint open sets $U_x$ and $V_x$ such that
$x\in U_x$ and $y\in V_x$. Then $\{U_x\}_{x\in A}$ is an open cover for
$A$. Using , it follows that there exist a finite set $A_0\subset A$
such that $\{U_x\}_{x\in A_0}$ is a finite open cover for $A$. Let us
define $$\begin{aligned}
U= \bigcup_{x\in A_0} U_x,\,\,\,\,\,&\,&\,\,\,\,\, V= \bigcap_{x\in A_0} V_x.\end{aligned}$$
Next we show that these sets satisfy the given conditions for $U$ and
$V$. First, it is clear that $U$ and $V$ are open. We also have that
$A\subset U$ and $y\in V$. To see that $U$ and $V$ are disjoint, suppose
$z\in U$. Then $z\in U_x$ for some $x\in A_0$. Since $U_x$ and $V_x$ are
disjoint, $z$ can not be in $V_x$, and consequently $z$ can not be in
$V$.

The above result and proof follows [@kelley] (Chapter 5, Theorem 7) or
[@singer] (page 27).

[9]{} J.L. Kelley, *General Topology*, D. van Nostrand Company, Inc.,
1955. I.M. Singer, J.A.Thorpe, *Lecture Notes on Elementary Topology and
Geometry*, Springer-Verlag, 1967.
names: point and a compact set in a Hausdorff space have  disjoint open neighborhoods.
